results.title: Egg-ceptional
results.brief_description: A deceptively simple film about an egg who doesn’t fit. Superb animation details the various stages of the production process where the egg who is ‘different’ fails to meet the required specifications. A film that operates on a number of levels ranging from lower primary concepts of colour, number and size to the more abstract concepts of conformity, individual differences, desire for acceptance, etc.

results.title: Desert regions: nomads and traders
results.creator_credit: Wolfgang Bayer and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: A comparison between two traditional cultures occupying desert lands and the ways in which both tribes customs are being forced into change. Suitable for middle and upper primary levels.

results.title: Boo Boo monster enters a beauty contest
results.creator_credit: Bill Cleary and Billy Budd Films
results.brief_description: A beautifully animated story about a friendly green monster who tries to change the colour of his skin and who learns he must accept himself as he really is. A rhythmic drum beat enhances the natural rhythm of the verse to which visuals are set. Animated by Tom Golden and Arnie Levey, music performed and composed by Herbert Harris.

results.title: Amphibians: frogs, toads and salamanders. - Rev. ed.
results.creator_credit: Paul Burnford and BFA Educational Media
results.brief_description: Uses excellent close-up photos and cinematography to show a typical amphibian life-cycle and to study the differences between three kinds of amphibians - frogs, toads and salamanders. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Drought (D)
results.creator_credit: Tristram Miall, Robert Loader and Golden Dolphin
results.brief_description: Powerful introduction to drought and other dramatic aspects of Australia’s climate, including bushfires, floods, cyclones. Examines how native plants and animals have adapted to these conditions, and looks at the history of European occupation. WARNING: Contains disturbing scenes of the agonising death of a herd of wild horses at a dry water hole and recommend viewing suitable for upper secondary student level only.

results.title: A Track winding back
results.brief_description: Presents a sketch of life in Gundagai, NSW around the turn of the century utilising contemporary photographs and written records. Covers architecture, fashion, medicine, politics, problems of workers, the departure of troops for the Boer War and the celebration of Commonwealth Day.

results.title: September '51
results.creator_credit: Raymond Quint and Australian Film and Television School
results.brief_description:
Looks at the Menzies LCP government’s attempt to ban the Communist Party in Australia in the referendum of 1951 through the dramatic portrayal of the life of a young couple who are members of the party. Highlights the near hysterical atmosphere of this period in Australia’s history.
Cast includes Martin Vaughn, Barry Otto and John Howard.

results.title: A Creative partnership: the actor and the director
results.creator_credit: Cynthia Controp, Eric Halliday and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Traces a segment of a feature film from casting to the actor-director relationship through these various stages. Very useful for senior media studies students as it makes tangible the relationship between the director and the actors. Also shows the actors negotiating their parts with the director, making input into how the part is to be played. Featuring Michael Caulfield as the director, Noni Hazelhurst and John Derum as the actors.

results.title: Wharfie
results.creator_credit: Barbara Boyd-Anderson and A Fitzroy Flix Film
results.brief_description: Impressionistic, non-narrated study of Melbourne Waterfront in which and old ex-wharfie returns to the wharves with his grandson to be confronted by vast technological changes. Still photographs and newspaper headlines refer back to more boisterous days when the wharves employed many more men.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Barbara Boyd-Anderson and A Fitzroy Flix Film

results.title: Shrink proofing wool
results.creator_credit: D.G. Corke, P. Bruce, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
results.brief_description: Describes early attempts to make wool shrink-resistant by chlorination and comments on some adverse effects of this process. It goes on toe cover CSIROs research efforts culminating in a coating technique using a resin polyamide epichlorhydrin. This method is used commercially and renders wool completely shrink proof. Reference is made to the parallel development of a method of continuous dyeing of wool and that these developments are compatible.
results.creator_credit_for_label: D.G. Corke, P. Bruce, S.T. Evans and CSIRO
